summary: Email correspondence from the DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) to the USAO-SDNY Chief of Public Corruption regarding the transfer of OPR's investigative records on the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein matter. The email discusses the format and limitations of the records for potential criminal discovery.

persons.name: Chief, Public Corruption USAO-SDNY
persons.role: Chief of Public Corruption Unit, U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York
persons.context: Recipient of the email from OPR regarding the transfer of investigative records related to the Epstein matter.

persons.name: Counsel, Office of Professional Responsibility
persons.role: Counsel, DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility
persons.context: Sender of the email, offering to provide OPR's electronic records from its investigation into the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein case.

connections.description: OPR counsel is communicating with the SDNY Public Corruption Chief regarding the transfer of investigative materials.

events.title: OPR Offers Epstein Investigation Records to SDNY
events.description: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility emails the USAO-SDNY Public Corruption Chief to offer electronic records from OPR's investigation into the USAO-SDFL's handling of the Epstein matter.

locations: U.S. Department of Justice, 950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NAV â€” Room 3266, Washington, D.C. 20530
keyFacts: The DOJ's Office of Professional Responsibility (OPR) conducted an investigation into the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida's (USAO-SDFL) handling of the Epstein matter.
OPR is prepared to provide its collected electronic records to the Public Corruption Unit of the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York (USAO-SDNY).
OPR provides a strong caveat that the records were collected for its administrative investigation and cannot be represented as complete for criminal discovery purposes.
The correspondence indicates ongoing investigative interest by SDNY in the Epstein case and the prior handling by the Florida office.
The email discusses logistical methods for transferring the records, either via encrypted hard drive or through the JEFS system.
